12. With similar EVs and market opportunity will be interesting to see how two stocks perform over the coming years. Does $ CMCSA Cable Comm business beat $ DIS catalog and scale?

11. Valuations Fox deal makes Pro Forma messy for $ DIS. I ballpark Pro Forma EV to be ~$240-260b. Current EV $185 + 36b of Debt + 343m new shares ($40b) - $15b in proceeds from SKY sale. Selling RSNs will further reduce EV. $ CMCSA EV = $280b ($172b Market Cap + $108 of Net Debt)
10. This may be anectdotal, but I view ESPN and Twitter as the de facto sources for Sports news. As sports rights evolve towards DTC offering, can $ CMCSA compete? TBD

9. In 2018 $ CMCSA did $1.8b of EBIT in Parks. $ CMCSA investing heavily in its Parks division - $4.8b of CapEx since 2011. $1.1b in 2018 alone. Expanding in US. Universal Japan to launch in 2020 before the Olympics in partnership with Nintendo.

8. Theme Parks at $ DIS have grown from $1.1b of EBIT in 1997 to $3.7b of EBIT in 2017 at Disney. 6% CAGR. I view this as more + for $ CMCSA as it shows the LT playbook for them to follow. Much smaller scale gives them larger/longer runway to grow.

5. The other thing to consider is the quality of $ CMCSA's Cable Communication business. I view this as an incredibly high quality business. Hard to see how anyone replicates their internet business. Expanding into Mobile/Safety makes product offering even stickier.

4. The direct relationship with customer represents the biggest advantage $ CMCSA currently has over $ DIS when it comes to OTT opportunity. Is customer data or catalog more important to launch? Time will tell.

2. Sky acquisition doubles the #of customers $ CMCSA has direct relationship with to 48-50m. Footprint of nearly 200m provides a long runway for growth. Sky leading DTC platform in Europe. In theory tech should support US launch and provide backbone of a global OTT platform. pic.twitter.com/QEjtkohmle
